title: How is Bangladesh portrayed in Pakistani textbooks? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the earlier school days, I came to know Bangladesh when I read about Muslim Countries in the World and South Asian Map. Other than this, Bangladesh was never a topic. I came to know more about Bangladesh when I saw their Cricket Team in 1999 WC in which Bangladesh defeated in form Pakistan team (Pakistani team was the finalist of the tournament). We were taught that all Muslims are brothers and so indirectly it means every Muslim country is like our friend (which include Bangladesh aswell). If you are particularly pointing towards the 1971, I would like to answer this too. I remember a chapter “Fall of Dhaka” in which I came to know that Bangladesh was previously East Pakistan. I also remember that the main reason which led to chaos was the language issue. We studied the reasons in details which gave me an impression that it was our (West Pakistan’s) fault due to which we lost a part. Now we have moved on and accepted Bangladesh as a separate country. Apart from this, I remember that I read in one of the books that Bangladesh produces a lot of jute. In a nut shell, there is nothing negative about Bangladesh in Pakistani textbooks. Btw, someone who visited Bangladesh told me that their team supports Pakistani team in Cricket and Shahid Afridi has a huge fan following there. I am not sure it is true or not but I am just writing what I heard. Someone also told me that for historical reasons, they are rude to Pakistanis when they apply for visa to visit Bangladesh. PS: I don’t hate Bangladesh or its people.

Unfortunately Bangladesh is not featured in textbooks at all. Pakistanis as whole don’t even know ABC of current Bangladesh. Pakistan’s history books provide all events in chronological order until the creation of Pakistan from there it goes on 16X speed of a DVD. All you read is Governor Generals, Prime ministers and Generals and their contribution. No context is given they just passed those constitutions and whatever 5 years development plans. Story of Bangladesh comes under War of 1971. East Pakistan became Bangladesh and POW were released in Shimla agreement. Mukti Bahini were Indian trained and funded. This is the high school book i am talking about. Of course if you want to study more then you will have to take history as a subject thats where whole scholarly debates start. There is not much i am afraid we have forgotten all about Bangladesh and don’t care. Only motivation we got out this is to take revenge from India. This approach is not right but since we still have an active conflict with India. It puts all the focus on this side. I am personally happy that Bangladesh is doing well and may you have many years of growth and prosperity. Thanks for reading

Like a brother country. You wont find any Pakistani disliking Bangladesh. Bangladesh is our younger brother who moved out, mostly due to our fault, and a neigbours constant annoying habit of sticking their nose where it doesnt belong ( their prime minister proudly admitted to breaking off a part of Pakistan ). We might be seperate countries but our core is one. We have the same Allah and the same Rasool (S.A.W), the same heroes, the same story, the same journey. If Bangladesh is hurt, we feel it as our pain. Those were the sentiments I was brought up with. I remember when I went to Umrah ( i was like 12 back then) , I wanted to meet someone from Bangladesh and tell them how sorry we are for all that happened. I did meet a really nice woman from Bangladesh. Me and my mom spent some time with her and told her for us its still East Pakistan .i.e. a part of our heart and soul. She said she felt the same way. It was a nice conversation. God I was sure I could make us one again. Not so naive now (still hoping though) :) but the love is the same. I do know the pain my grandparents felt who migrated to Pakistan from India and they fought India from west Pakistan. Their diaries from that time break your heart. They write how their entire units sat and cried for days. It felt like loosing a brother. Love, from Pakistan.

Based on my experience, majority of the Pakistani people don’t care about what go on in Bangladesh. They are busy with their own lives. In most cases, they are sympathetic to the people of Bangladesh because of shared religious beliefs. On the other hand, the current ruling party in Bangladesh, the awami league, wants to use the anti-Pakistani sentiment to justify their one party autocratic rule and staying in power with force. They have been doing it for years and it seems to be working recently. As long as people stay dumb, they can continue their evil rule. People need to rise up again to establish their voting rights and not fall into the trap of these type of silliness.

Hmmmmmm……,Very Intersting Question. First,Bangladesh is always portrayed as our Islamic Brother Country Which was once Part of Pakistan,But due to Military And Political Establishment Cruelty In Bangladesh And By not giving them their due rights Were alienated from Pakistan.There was also a major role of India in all this scenario.But Common Pakistanis Think Bangladesh as their lost brother.

Bangladesh is always portrayed in a positive way. We were one nation but unfortunately due to a few people we got separated. But there is no negative thing written in our books against Bangladesh. In Pakistani textbooks, our historians and book writers blame India for the separation of both countries. We don’t hate Bangladesh. Can you please tell me how your Textbooks portrays us? Thanks
